titleStmt.title: The Distress'd Maid being put to her
last Shift,
Maketh her Petition to the Reverend Dr.
Swift.

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: In Imitation of Frances Harris's Petition.
Humbly Shewing,THAT Your Petitioner being about Twenty-five Years of Age, has never yet been a Bride,
Tho' Co-Heiress to an Estate of Eight-hundred Pounds per Anuum beside;
And your Petitioner's Mother, who is old enough to be her Grannum,
Has a Jointure out of the said Estate of Two-hundred Pounds per Annum,
Which, together with some Incumbrances on the said Estate,
Has kept your Petitioner's Maiden-Head at a very low Rate:
However (as the saying is) let a Con-cern never so little bring,
Yet the Limb of an Estate, is a very pretty Thing;Wherefore, and in Consideration of which, a certain C────k
Thought it meet and proper to become your Petitioner's Spark!
So to Clear off Part of the Estate Two-thousand Five-hundred Pounds he tender'd,
On Condition your Petitioner were to him forthwith Surrender'd,
So that having gotten the Mortgages in his Name, and me for his Wife,
He might have an Estate, In Tail, thereby on your Petitioner's Life.
These fair Proposals wrought so far on your Petitioner's Mother;
That she wou'd marry her Daughter to him, and no other
Hoping, as he was both a Man of Fortune and Honour,

That he wou'd make a very handsome Settlement upon her.B────ty, quoth she, by the World, we have caught a Gudgeon── quoth I, I warrant, as taking it in dudgeon.Why? you Hussey, she reply'd, falling into a very great Passion,You shall Marry him, it's very well known, he is a Man of good Fashion.
Ay, marry!
His Riches will make amends for his lack of Youth and Beauty:
So I Consented, as you know, it was my Duty.────
But when the Writings were Drawn the Man, he wou'd not Settle──
And this, as you may well suppose, set my Mother upon her Mettle;
Quoth she, I hope, the Matter is not yet so far gone,.
Good Mr. P────, by your leave, there are two Words to a Bargain
Now, you must know, I wou'd Marry the Man with an Inch of a Candle,
Yet, it seems, my Mother having taken this as a Handle,
Will not be brought by any means at-all to Submission,
And for the Man's part, he'll Marry me upon no other Condition.
“The Premisses tenderly consider'd,” I beg you will use your Discretion,
And go to your Petitioner's Mother, to make Intercession;
In order that she and the C────k may make up the aforesaid Breach:
And your Petitioner, (as in Duty Bound) shall Pray, as long as you shall Preach.
